sources.title: Vegan Dishes to Feel Connected to Latin American Culture
sources.content:
+ Black beans and onions
  + Sweet corn
  + Potatoes
  + Refried pinto beans and vegan cheese
  + Jackfruit with tomato, cilantro, and onion
  + Vegan cheese and jalapeños
  + Plant-based meat
 Enchiladas (possible fillings & combinations)
  + Vegan cheese
  + Vegan cheese with spinach
  + Vegan cheese with chickpeas
  + Vegan cheese with refried pinto beans
  + Plant-based meat
  + Toppings: plant based sour cream, avocado, pico de gallo, salsa
 Posole (traditional Mexican stew)
  + Base: vegetable stock, hominy corn
  + Extra: lettuce, cabbage, chili peppers, onion, garlic, avocado, salsa or limes
 Soups
  + Base: beans or lentils
  + Extra: zucchini, carrots, celery, potatoes, cabbage, cilantro
 Chilaquiles (traditional Mexican breakfast dish) [...] + Potatoes with bell peppers
  + Sweet potato with black beans
  + Vegan cheese
  + Cashew
  + Jelly (like strawberry) with vegan cream cheese
  + Apple and vegan caramelized milk
 Chalupas (traditional Mexican flat, but heavier taco) – (possible fillings)
  + Base: potatoes, refried beans
  + Toppings: avocado, vegan cheese, tomato, cilantro, lettuce, vegan sour cream
 Arroz con Gandules (traditional Puerto Rican rice and beans)
  + Base: rice and beans (pigeon peas)
  + Toppings: Cilantro
 Arepas (traditional Colombian and Venezuelan cornmeal cake) – (possible fillings)
  + Arepas – naturally vegan, changes with filling
  + Fillings: black/pinto beans, vegan cheese, avocado, cilantro, tomato, corn, plantains, jackfruit
 Mole (traditional Mexican sauce traditionally poured over meat) – [...] Chilaquiles (traditional Mexican breakfast dish)
  + Base: tortillas chips (roast or fry), egg substitute (such as Just Egg)
  + Extra: beans, lettuce, avocado, cilantro
 Salad of…
  + Nopale (cactus)
  + Lettuce
  + Spinach
  + Toppings: tomato, avocado, black/pinto beans, chickpeas, corn, shredded vegan cheese, tofu
 Sopa de frijoles (traditional Honduran bean soup)
  + Base: black/pinto beans
  + Toppings: cilantro, tomato, onion, avocado
 Baleadas (traditional Honduran breakfast tacos)
  + Base: flour tortilla, egg substitute (such as Just Egg), refried pinto beans
  + Toppings: avocado, shredded vegan cheese
 Empanadas (traditional baked/fried bread with filling) – (possible fillings & combinations)
  + Tempeh, onion, potatoes, bell peppers
  + Potatoes with bell peppers

sources.title: 8 Best Vegan Dishes in South America
sources.content:

# Top 8 South American Vegan Dishes

Last updated on January 16, 2026

###### Table of contents

 Best South American Vegan Dishes
 About this ranking
 User comments
 Similar lists

01

### Berenjenas en escabeche

Argentina

3.9 ·

Berenjenas en escabeche is a classic Argentinian side dish consisting of eggplant slices that are boiled in a water-vinegar mixture with bay leaves until tender. They are then left to soak in a jar filled with olive oil, crushed red pepper, dried oregano, and garlic. These flavorful eggplant slices can be consumed as an appetizer, an interesting sandwich filling, or as a perfect accompaniment to traditional Argentinian asado.

Read more

Best restaurants [...] Read more

06

### Arroz graneado

Chile

n/a ·

Arroz graneado or grained rice is a simple Chilean rice dish made with long-grained white rice that is cooked with golden-fried minced garlic and (optionally) carrots. It is traditionally served as a side dish accompanying bigger meals. If desired, the rice can be enriched with onions, bell peppers, or chopped parsley. It is important that the grains remain fluffy and separated, otherwise it is not considered a true arroz graneado.

Read more

07

### Arroz arvejado

Lambayeque, Peru

n/a · [...] Read more

03

### Ceviche de chochos

Ancash, Peru

2.7 ·

Ceviche de chochos is a traditional and Ecuatorian dish in made with chochos or tarwi (lupini beans) as the primary ingredient. These beans have a unique, slightly bitter flavor that pairs well with the acidic components of the dish. The chochos are mixed with ingredients typical of ceviche preparations, like tomatoes, onions, coriander, lime juice, and usually aji peppers. The mix is left to marinate, allowing the flavors to meld. Often, ceviche de chochos is garnished with toasted corn (maiz tostado), chifles (thin plantain chips), or avocado slices. The combination of textures – the softness of the beans, the crunch of the corn, and the creaminess of the avocado – adds to the appeal of the dish.

Read more

04

sources.title: Vegan Delights: Exploring South American Cuisine
sources.content: We went down in search of the legendary sands of the Copacabana, and we also went in search of food. What we found was a wonderful mix of indigenous South American ingredients with Portuguese influence and often touched with African spice. Like most of the Americas, Brazil is a melting pot – a delicious consequence of exploration and colonization. We found a vegetarian feijoada, Brazil’s national dish, that was served in a clay pot, its spicy fragrant steam mingling with the salt air of the beach footsteps away. The vegetarian version tops stewed black beans with fresh hearts of palm, orange, and collards. [...] most famous chile), dried olive, peanut and cilantro. Who in the culinary world can get away with putting peanuts, olives and cilantro on the same dish? The Peruvian chefs can and they pull it off effortlessly in a fascinating mix of flavors and textures that just seem to always work. [...] We also found a vegetarian moqueca, a Brazilian classic traditionally made with fish stewed with coconut milk and chilies. The vegetarian version did not disappoint, made with several varieties of squash in a rich coconut broth scented with fresh cilantro, chilies and lime.

messages.content: South American vegan recipes predominantly feature bean-based dishes, corn and corn products, and utilize ingredients like jackfruit and heart of palm as meat substitutes. Citrus and fresh herbs are crucial for flavor. There's a strong pattern of adapting traditional dishes into vegan versions, incorporating a wide variety of vegetables and fruits, with rice and grains serving as common staples.

structured_output.draft:
## Popular Vegan Recipes in South America

South American vegan cuisine is characterized by its innovative use of plant-based ingredients to recreate traditional flavors and textures. Bean-based dishes, corn and its derivatives, and versatile ingredients like jackfruit and heart of palm are central to many popular vegan recipes across the continent.

### Key Ingredients and Flavor Profiles

*   **Legumes and Grains:** Beans form the foundation of numerous dishes, providing protein and substance. Rice and other grains are common staples, accompanying a wide array of vegetable preparations.
*   **Corn Products:** Corn, a staple grain, is featured in various forms, from fresh kernels to masa for tamales and arepas.
*   **Meat Substitutes:** Ingredients such as jackfruit and heart of palm are frequently employed to mimic the texture of meat in adapted traditional dishes.
*   **Flavor Enhancers:** Citrus fruits and fresh herbs play a critical role in delivering vibrant and fresh flavor profiles to South American vegan meals.

### Adaptation of Traditional Dishes

A significant trend in South American vegan cooking is the adaptation of classic, non-vegan dishes into plant-based versions. This approach allows for the preservation of cultural culinary heritage while catering to vegan dietary preferences. These adaptations often incorporate a broad spectrum of local vegetables and fruits, ensuring rich and diverse culinary experiences.

### Examples of Popular Vegan Dishes

While specific regional popularity can vary, common themes emerge:

*   **Bean Stews and Soups:** Hearty stews and soups featuring various beans (black beans, lentils, chickpeas) with vegetables and spices are prevalent.
*   **Corn-Based Preparations:** Dishes like vegan tamales, arepas filled with plant-based ingredients, and corn chowders are popular.
*   **Jackfruit 'Pulled Pork' or 'Carnitas':** Jackfruit is used to create savory fillings for tacos, empanadas, or as a main component in barbecue-style dishes.
*   **Heart of Palm 'Ceviche' or 'Tuna Salad':** Heart of palm is often used as a seafood substitute in dishes like ceviche or in salads mimicking tuna salad.
*   **Vegetable-Heavy Stir-fries and Rice Dishes:** Utilizing the abundant local produce, many vegan meals involve stir-fried vegetables served with rice or other grains.

Overall, South American vegan recipes emphasize fresh, whole ingredients, creative meat and seafood alternatives, and the adaptation of beloved traditional dishes to be entirely plant-based.
sections: Popular Vegan Recipes in South America

The structure is logical, with clear sections on ingredients, adaptations, and examples. The writing is clear and easy to understand.

Identifies key ingredients and flavor profiles.
Highlights the adaptation of traditional dishes.
Offers specific examples of popular dishes.
weaknesses: Could benefit from mentioning more specific dishes from the provided sources, such as dishes with their country of origin and ingredients (e.g. Berenjenas en escabeche (Argentina), Ceviche de chochos (Peru/Ecuador), Feijoada (Brazil)).
actionable_feedback: Include more specific dish examples with their countries of origin and key ingredients, drawing from the provided sources (e.g., TasteAtlas, Thecookscook.com).
Add more specific dish examples from the provided sources like the Veganuary recipes to provide more diverse examples.
While not strictly required, adding some form of citations would improve the draft's credibility.

full_state.draft:
## Popular Vegan Recipes in South America

South American vegan cuisine is characterized by its innovative use of plant-based ingredients to recreate traditional flavors and textures. Bean-based dishes, corn and its derivatives, and versatile ingredients like jackfruit and heart of palm are central to many popular vegan recipes across the continent.

### Key Ingredients and Flavor Profiles

*   **Legumes and Grains:** Beans form the foundation of numerous dishes, providing protein and substance. Rice and other grains are common staples, accompanying a wide array of vegetable preparations.
*   **Corn Products:** Corn, a staple grain, is featured in various forms, from fresh kernels to masa for tamales and arepas.
*   **Meat Substitutes:** Ingredients such as jackfruit and heart of palm are frequently employed to mimic the texture of meat in adapted traditional dishes.
*   **Flavor Enhancers:** Citrus fruits and fresh herbs play a critical role in delivering vibrant and fresh flavor profiles to South American vegan meals.

### Adaptation of Traditional Dishes

A significant trend in South American vegan cooking is the adaptation of classic, non-vegan dishes into plant-based versions. This approach allows for the preservation of cultural culinary heritage while catering to vegan dietary preferences. These adaptations often incorporate a broad spectrum of local vegetables and fruits, ensuring rich and diverse culinary experiences.

### Examples of Popular Vegan Dishes

While specific regional popularity can vary, common themes emerge:

*   **Bean Stews and Soups:** Hearty stews and soups featuring various beans (black beans, lentils, chickpeas) with vegetables and spices are prevalent.
*   **Corn-Based Preparations:** Dishes like vegan tamales, arepas filled with plant-based ingredients, and corn chowders are popular.
*   **Jackfruit 'Pulled Pork' or 'Carnitas':** Jackfruit is used to create savory fillings for tacos, empanadas, or as a main component in barbecue-style dishes.
*   **Heart of Palm 'Ceviche' or 'Tuna Salad':** Heart of palm is often used as a seafood substitute in dishes like ceviche or in salads mimicking tuna salad.
*   **Vegetable-Heavy Stir-fries and Rice Dishes:** Utilizing the abundant local produce, many vegan meals involve stir-fried vegetables served with rice or other grains.

Overall, South American vegan recipes emphasize fresh, whole ingredients, creative meat and seafood alternatives, and the adaptation of beloved traditional dishes to be entirely plant-based.

  + Cilantro

  + Alternatives: plant-based milk (it’s popular to use coconut milk), organic brown sugar, coconut cream
 Churros (traditional Latin American fried dough)
  + Alternatives: plant-based milk, egg substitute (such as Just Egg), organic brown sugar or white sugar
 Conchas (traditional Mexican sweet bread roll)
  + Alternatives: plant-based milk, egg substitute (such as Just Egg, aquafaba, chickpea or garbanzo bean juice), organic brown sugar or white sugar
  + Fillings: sweet potato
 Pastelitos de Queso (traditional Cuban cream cheese pastry)
  + Fillings: Miyoko’s cottage cheese, vegan Greek yogurt, hummus, silken tofu
 Pastelitos de Espinaca (traditional Argentinian spinach empanadas) [...] + Potatoes with bell peppers

sources.title: 15 Plant-Based South American Recipes – One Green Planet
sources.content:
Source: Black Bean Potato Pupusas

A pupusa is a traditional Salvadoran dish consisting of a thick corn tortilla filled with a blend of meat, cheese, and beans. However, these Black Bean Potato Pupusas by Jasmine Briones are vegan, gluten-free, and oil-free! Oh yeah, and they’re just as good as any pupusa you can find at a street cart.

## 15. Roasted Poblano Cilantro Empanadas

Roasted Poblano Cilantro Empanadas

messages.content: The analysis of the provided data reveals that tacos, empanadas, beans, and corn are prominent in South American vegan cuisine. Vegan cheese and plant-based alternatives are frequently used to adapt traditional dishes. The data suggests a focus on adapting existing recipes with readily available vegan substitutes.

main_insights.title: Tacos and Empanadas are Popular Vegan Options
main_insights.description: Tacos and empanadas appear frequently as popular choices in South American vegan cuisine. They can be adapted with various fillings, making them versatile and appealing.
supporting_evidence: Sweet Heat Tacos listed on Veganuary
Crunchy Cous Cous Tacos with a Sweet n’ Spicy Jalapeno Dressing listed on Veganuary
Roasted Poblano Cilantro Empanadas are featured as a recipe on One Green Planet
Empanadas are mentioned with various vegan fillings like tempeh, potatoes, and bell peppers

main_insights.title: Beans and Corn are Staple Ingredients
main_insights.description: Black beans, pinto beans, and corn (including hominy) are consistently used in a variety of South American vegan dishes, showcasing their importance in the cuisine.
supporting_evidence: Black Bean Chilli listed on Veganuary
Black beans and onions mentioned as enchilada filling.
Refried pinto beans and vegan cheese mentioned as enchilada filling.
Posole uses hominy corn.
Sopa de frijoles (bean soup) uses black/pinto beans.
Pupusas are traditionally filled with beans.
Arepas can be filled with black/pinto beans.

main_insights.title: Vegan Cheese and Plant-Based Alternatives are Common
main_insights.description: Vegan cheese, plant-based meat alternatives, and egg substitutes are frequently incorporated into traditionally non-vegan dishes to create vegan versions.
supporting_evidence: Vegan CHIK’N Enchiladas listed on Veganuary
Vegan cheese mentioned as an enchilada, chalupa and salad ingredient.
Plant-based meat mentioned as an enchilada filling
Egg substitute used in chilaquiles and baleadas
Plant-based milk used in desserts

patterns.name: Adaptation of Traditional Dishes
patterns.description: Many vegan recipes are adaptations of traditional South American dishes, substituting animal products with plant-based alternatives.
examples: Vegan Enchiladas using plant-based chicken and vegan cheese.
Vegan Manjar (dulce de leche) using plant-based milk.
Vegan Pupusas using black bean and potato filling instead of meat and cheese.

patterns.name: Use of Salsas and Dips
patterns.description: Salsas and dips, often naturally vegan, play a significant role in South American cuisine and are frequently used as toppings or accompaniments.
examples: Chimole, Pico de Gallo, Sofrito, Corn or mango salsa all naturally vegan

recommendations: Investigate regional variations in vegan recipes to identify the most popular dishes in specific South American countries.
Analyze the frequency of ingredient usage across different recipes to determine staple vegan ingredients in South American cuisine.
Compare traditional recipes with their vegan adaptations to understand common substitutions and modifications.
Explore the use of specific plant-based meat and dairy alternatives in South American vegan cooking.
Research the cultural significance of dishes and ingredients to provide context to the vegan recipes.
structured_output.summary: The analysis of the provided data reveals that tacos, empanadas, beans, and corn are prominent in South American vegan cuisine. Vegan cheese and plant-based alternatives are frequently used to adapt traditional dishes. The data suggests a focus on adapting existing recipes with readily available vegan substitutes.

structured_output.draft:
## Popular Vegan Recipes in South America

South American vegan cuisine is characterized by the adaptation of traditional dishes using plant-based ingredients and readily available vegan substitutes. The analysis highlights several popular food categories and specific dishes that are frequently prepared in vegan variations.

### Key Ingredients and Adaptations

*   **Tacos and Empanadas:** These portable and versatile dishes are very popular and often found in vegan versions. Adaptations typically involve replacing traditional meat fillings with plant-based alternatives such as beans, lentils, or seasoned vegetables.
*   **Beans and Corn:** Staple ingredients like beans and corn are foundational to many South American vegan recipes. They are used as main components or as hearty fillings and sides.
*   **Vegan Cheese and Plant-Based Alternatives:** The incorporation of vegan cheese and other plant-based alternatives is a common strategy to mimic the texture and flavor of traditional dairy and meat products, making familiar dishes accessible to vegans.

### Culinary Trends

The overarching trend in South American vegan cooking appears to be the creative modification of existing, beloved recipes. This approach allows for the preservation of cultural culinary heritage while embracing plant-based eating. The focus is on utilizing accessible ingredients and straightforward substitutions to achieve delicious vegan meals.
sections: Popular Vegan Recipes in South America

scores.reasoning: The draft directly addresses the query about popular vegan recipes in South America.

The draft accurately reflects the information found in the sources, detailing popular dishes and key ingredients used in South American vegan cuisine. It correctly identifies the trend of adapting traditional dishes.
The draft covers key aspects like ingredients, adaptations, and culinary trends. While it's not exhaustive, it provides a good overview based on the provided sources.
The writing is clear and easy to understand. The structure with sections on ingredients, adaptations, and trends helps organize the information.

strengths: Accurately summarizes information from the sources.
Provides a clear and concise overview of South American vegan cuisine.
Identifies key ingredients and the trend of adapting traditional dishes.
weaknesses: Could benefit from more specific examples of recipes from the sources.
Could expand on the different countries and their specific dishes from the VRG source.
actionable_feedback: Include more specific examples of recipes mentioned in the sources (e.g., from One Green Planet, Veganuary or VRG).
